raw_comment: This graph is highly relatable to my experience right now as a high school senior. It shows the advantage that legacy students have at Ivy League schools. You can tell from the graph that having a parent attend that college raises the applicant's chances significantly, but interestingly, it most affects the rich. This is most likely because wealthy people tend to donate to their alma mater, especially when they have a child hoping to attend that school.  This shows how the college selection process has become increasingly biased and no longer based on the student and their accomplishment. Money makes the world go around, and colleges are businesses, so income is their main focus. The more wealthy can provide this, especially when their multigenerational legacies and alumni of these institutions. I would title this graph: "College Admissions: Money Talks."
ace_sentences: I am a high school senior.
This graph is relatable to my experience now.
This graph shows an advantage of legacy students at Ivy League schools.
A legacy student is a student who has a parent who attended the same college.
The graph shows that a parent who attended a college increases the chance of admission for an applicant to this college.
The graph shows that this effect is strongest for rich applicants.
Wealthy people tend to donate to their alma mater.
Some wealthy people have a child who hopes to attend the same school.
If a wealthy person has such a child, then the wealthy person tends to donate to the alma mater.
This situation shows that the college selection process has become increasingly biased.
This situation shows that the college selection process is no longer based on the student and the accomplishments of the student.
Income is a main focus of colleges.
Wealthy people can provide more income to colleges than non-wealthy people.
Some wealthy applicants are multigenerational legacies.
Some wealthy applicants are alumni of these institutions.
The title of this graph is: College Admissions: Money Talks.
